metadata.title: Impact of Nano-TiO2 on the NO2 degradation and rheological performance of asphalt pavement

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Impact of Nano-TiO2 on the NO2 degradation and rheological performance of asphalt pavement
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.05.075 0950-0618/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author at: School of Traffic and Transportation Engineering, Changsha University of Science & Technology, Changsha 410114, China.
E-mail address: huanan.yu@csust.edu.cn (H. Yu).
Guoping Qian a,b, Huanan Yu a,b,⇑, Xiangbing Gong a,b, Lu Zhao b aNational Engineering Laboratory for Highway Maintenance Technology, Changsha University of Science & Technology, Changsha 410114, China b School of Traffic and Transportation Engineering, Changsha University of Science & Technology, Changsha 410114, China
h i g h l i g h t s
TiO2 photocatalyst with asphalt binder efficiently degrade NO2. TiO2 increase the rutting resistance of asphalt in high temperature. TiO2 do not have significant impact on low temperature cracking resistance. Cationic surfactant increase the rutting resistance of asphalt. Cationic surfactant decrease the cracking resistance at low temperature.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 December 2018 Received in revised form 14 February 2019 Accepted 8 May 2019 Available online 30 May 2019
Keywords: Nano-titanium dioxide NO2 degradation Photo-catalytic Asphalt mixture Rheological property Aging characteristic
a b s t r a c t
This research carried out the NO2 degradation performance and asphalt pavement performance of SBS modified asphalt with different content (0%, 1%, 2%, 5%, 10%) of nano-TiO2, and the impact of cationic surfactant were evaluated as well. The nano-TiO2 modified asphalt was prepared for Dynamic Shear Rheometer (DSR) test, Bending Beam Rheometer (BBR) test, Rolling Thin Film Oven Test (RTFOT) and Pressure Aging Vessel (PAV) test. And the high temperature performance, low temperature performance and aging properties were evaluated. Results show that the nano-TiO2 increased the rutting resistance of asphalt in high-temperature especially when the content increased from 0% to 1%, and it did not have a significant impact on low temperature cracking resistance. Secondly, this research developed an innovative photo-reactive and measuring system, and simulated the NO2 degradation environment based on field data of varies typical roadway sections. Then, this research conducted photo-catalytic degradation test of NO2 for asphalt mixture with 5% nano-TiO2 content. The analysis shows that there are reversible reaction between NO2 and N2O4, and results indicated that the asphalt mixture has exhibited NO2 degradation effects. This research provided a deep understanding for the road performance and engineering application of nano-TiO2 modified asphalt mixture.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
1.1. Research background
sections.text:
Under the circumstance that car ownership continues to increase and environment pollution is becoming increasingly severe, how to control vehicle exhaust pollution has become an important problem all around the world. Researchers have
conducted extensive investigations to explore materials which are able to degrade NO2, and it was found that, as photocatalytic material, certain nano-particles can undergo redox reaction under UV irradiation to achieve the degradation of harmful substances [1]. In 1972, Fujishima and Hond [2] found that TiO2 has catalytic redox properties under light irradiation. Brown (1984) [3], Cui et al (1995) [4], Voront et al.(2003) [5] analyzed that TiO2 can applied as photocatalyst to oxidize and degrade harmful gases such as NO2 and CO; Muggli et al (2000) [6], Lee et al. (2004) [7] pointed out that TiO2 can degrade NO2, atmospheric sulfides and organic waste gas, and can be used for indoor air quality treatment.
With the increasing pollution of traffic environment, researchers began to study the application of nano-TiO2 in highway engineering. Many cities around the world have carried out researches and engineering applications and have achieved instructive results. For example, Chiba, Japan built a highway that uses the pore structure on the road surface to load TiO2 powder to achieve the effect of photocatalytic degradation of automobile exhaust gas [8]. In 2002, researchers in Milan, Italy evaluated the photocatalytic degradation effect of nano-TiO2 and laid a test section of 7000 m2 in the form of coating [9]. The Antwerp City Park in Belgium constructed a sidewalk of about 10,000 m2 with cement concrete bricks containing nano-TiO2 [10]. In Guerville, France, nano-TiO2 was sprayed on the walls of three buildings to study its degradation of NO2 in the atmosphere [11]. Chen et al (2006, 2007) found that the cured cement specimens exhibited good degradation performance of NO2 in the atmosphere under UV irradiation [12]. Zouzelka et al, investigated the photocatalytic activity of nano-TiO2 with regard to NO and NO2 abatement and have applied to the surface of concrete walls in field, and the photocatalytic coating maintained high effectivity after two years of service [13]. João Victor Staub de Melo et al produced blocks with a photocatalytic surface through the incorporation of TiO2 [14]. Qian et al. prepared cement concrete specimens by spraying nanoTiO2 water-borne slurry during the curing process of cement concrete, and constructed the test section of Nanjing toll station to test the degrading efficiency of NO2 on pavement, and found that meteorological conditions (such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, etc.) had significant effect on NO2 degradation [15]. M. PérezNicolás evaluated the Portland cements with two doped TiO2 (FeTiO2 and V-TiO2) photocatalysts and found those enhanced NO removal under visible light [16].
Previous studies on cement concrete pavement show that nanoTiO2 can degrade harmful substances by oxidation-reduction reaction under UV irradiation. However, the portion of concrete cement pavement is less than 10% all around the world which is far less than that of asphalt pavement. Therefore, how to apply nanoTiO2 to develop environmental friendly asphalt pavement with TiO2 has become an important topic for researchers. Hassan et al. (2011) analyzed the degradation performance of NOx by adding TiO2 into asphalt specimens, and found that the physical properties of asphalt were not adversely affected after adding nano-TiO2 [17]. Yang et al. analyzed the influence of TiO2 on penetration, ductility and softening point of asphalt, and provided reference for determining the amount of TiO2 additive in engineering practice [18]. Zhang et al found that nano-TiO2 modified asphalt had the ability to resist UV aging [19].
In analyzing the pavement performance of nano-TiO2 asphalt mixture, Ye et al. found that nano-TiO2 powder can improve the pavement performance of asphalt mixture comprehensively by high temperature rutting test, low temperature bending beam rheology test and residual stability test [20]. Tan et al. found that the content of nano-TiO2 needed by the incorporation method was much larger than that of the coating method when the same degradation effect was achieved [21]. Chen et al. used a magnetic stirrer and ultrasonic dispersion technology to prepare TiO2 permeate,
which was coated on the surface of open-grade asphalt mixture (OGFC) by spray gun. The NOx catalytic degradation performance of the specimen before and after wearing was studied and the permeation effect of the prepared permeate was analyzed [22]. Sun et al [23] have studied the decomposition effect of nano-TiO2 on NOx under different mixing order and gradation of asphalt mixture and have concluded that the direct mixing method is suitable for large-scale road construction. In Shanghai, the construction of incorporating nano-TiO2 into OGFC asphalt mixture was carried out, and a test section of 180 m 29.5 m was laid to verify the degradation efficiency of nano-TiO2 for NOx in automobile exhaust. And after one year of field use, the sampling test results show that it still has good catalytic degradation efficiency, indicating that the asphalt pavement structure has good fixation effect on nano-TiO2 [24]. Wang, et al [25,26] developed a newmethod to coat TiO2 onto asphalt pavements with the aim to enhance the NOx decomposition efficiency and durability of the coating material for asphalt pavements. In this method, pulverized TiO2-cement mortar is used as the spreading material, which is bonded to asphalt pavement surface by epoxy resin. Fan et al [27] conducted chamber tests of NOx removal under simulated condition and show that NOx removal by C-TiO2 photocatalytic asphalt is viable and is better than conventional used P25. Shafabakhsh et al. [28], Cao et al. [29] also conducted experimental investigation of effect of nanoTiO2 modified bitumen on the performance of asphalt mixtures.
Through the above research results, it is found that most researches are focused on the methods of incorporating nanoTiO2 into cement concrete and how to achieve good dispersion effect and good durability in concrete pavement application. However, the application of nano-TiO2 in asphalt pavement still needs to be improved, the existing research mainly evaluates the influence of nano-TiO2 on asphalt binder from three major indicators of asphalt and aging test, which lacks the consideration of the actual filed temperature, humidity and UV intensity. In the aspect of nano-TiO2 modified asphalt mixture degrading automobile exhaust, existing studies on testing the degrading efficiency were mainly with mixed gas, which has a big difference with the composition of automobile exhaust in the field. Therefore, this research is based on investigations and field data collection of typical road sections of Guangzhou (China), the concentration range of NO2 in automobile exhaust at different time periods and traffic flows is obtained. And designed the indoor simulation test according to the actual environmental conditions, the impact of TiO2 on the rheological properties of asphalt and the NO2 degradation performance tests were conducted and analyzed.

sections.heading: 1.2. Research objectives and plans
sections.text: The experiment design and research flowchart are shown in Fig. 1. The detailed research plans are shown below:

sections.heading: 1.2.1. Determination of UV intensity and NO2 gas concentration in tests
sections.text: The UV intensity and NO2 concentration in photocatalytic degradation was determined according to the field data of typical road sections in Guangzhou as well as the classification standard of UV intensity in China.

sections.heading: 1.2.2. Asphalt material design and performance evaluation of nanoTiO2 impact
sections.text: The DSR and BBR tests of asphalt specimens with different nano-TiO2 content (0%, 1%, 2%, 5%, 10%) were carried out. The aging test of asphalt specimens before and after nano-TiO2 was analyzed and the effects of nano-TiO2 on low temperature, high temperature and aging properties of asphalt were summarized.

sections.heading: 1.2.3. NO2 Degradation performance test of asphalt mixtures with nano-TiO2
sections.text: AC-13C fine-graded asphalt mixture was selected in this research. The rutting plate with 5% nano-TiO2 content was prepared. Degradation experiments were conducted under simulated field environment (light intensity, gas concentration, temperature and humidity), and the effect of nano-TiO2 on the degradation of NO2 was analyzed.

sections.heading: 2. Methodology and experiments
2.1. Nano-TiO2 material properties
sections.text:
TiO2 has advantages of abundant sources and relatively lower cost, which occurs in nature as well-knownminerals rutile, anatase and brookite, the main resource to produce is TiO2 from ilmenite ore [30]. The TiO2 used in the experiment is VK-TG01 type nanoTiO2 produced by Hangzhou Wan Jing Advanced Material Co.,
Table 1 Technical indexes of VK-TG01 nano-TiO2.
Appearance Crystal Moisture
White powder Anatase 0.5% Density (g/cm3) Purity pH Value 3.16 99.8% 8.1
(a) Particle size
Fig. 2. Particle size
Ltd. (China), the main technical indexes of VK-TG01 nano-TiO2 were show in Table 1.
Particle size analysis test was carried out at room temperature and dispersed by ethanol ultrasonic for 1 h. The experimental results were shown in Fig. 2(a), however, it was found that nanoTiO2 usually occurred agglomeration during storage and transportation, so the particle size can be observed through scanning electron microscopy is 5-mm, the scanning electron microscopy results were shown in Fig. 2(b). Since the pH value of nano-TiO2 is 8.1, and the surface of the particles is negatively charged, so the addition of cationic surfactants can effectively improve the agglomeration phenomenon of nano-particles. Therefore, a group of asphalt samples with 5% nano-TiO2 + 0.2% cationic surfactant were supplemented to conduct the compare test of basic properties of asphalt samples with 5% nano-TiO2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Asphalt binder test and mixture design
2.2.1. Asphalt material sample prepare and tests
sections.text:
The DSR and BBR tests of asphalt specimens with different nano-TiO2 content (0%, 1%, 2%, 5%, 10%) were conducted, and the RTFOT was carried out to analyze the aging properties of asphalt binders before and after adding nano-TiO2. The asphalt used in the test is Donghai SBS modified asphalt, the basic properties of results are shown in Table 2. The experimental results show that the selected SBS modified asphalt meets the technical requirements of JTG F40-2004 (China).
The procedures of mixing nano-TiO2 with asphalt is below: Firstly, dried the nano-TiO2 to constant weight in an oven at 105 C, and heated SBS modified asphalt to 170 C. Secondly, nano-TiO2 was added according to the corresponding amount and stirred manually for 5–10 min, and then adjust the highspeed shearing apparatus to 8000 rad/min, and continue stirring for (30 ± 5) min. The naming of asphalt with different content of nano-TiO2 is shown in Table 3.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Asphalt mixture design
sections.text:
The AC-13C dense graded asphalt mixture is used in this research, the aggregate is limestone, and the gradation curve is
Particle Size(nm) Specific Surface Area(m2/g)
20 50–100 Avg Relative Density Hydrophilic coefficient g 3.95 0.559
(b) Scanning electron microscopy of nano-TiO2
analysis test.
shown in Fig. 3 which is following the JTGF40-2004 ‘‘Standard Test Methods of Bitumen and Bituminous Mixture for Highway Engineering”. The optimum asphalt content is 5.2%, the test sample air void is 5.0%, the VMA is 16.1% and VFA is 67.2%. The rutting plates with 5% nano-TiO2 content are prepared, and the Marshall test results show that the asphalt mixture meets the standard requirements.
2.3. Experimental setup of NO2 degradation with TiO2 asphalt mixture

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Photocatalytic reaction chamber
sections.text: A set of photocatalytic reactor was designed according to the needs of experiment, including closed photocatalytic reactor, experiment gas, gas injection needle for different gas concentration and high precision NO2 gas analyzer (the precision is 0.001 ppm). The size of the whole reaction chamber is 1600 * 870 * 740 mm3, and two rutting plates (600 mm wide) were arranged side by side on the push-pull shelf of the reaction chamber. The net volume of the whole reaction chamber after removing the photocatalytic test plates is about 1 m3.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Light intensity
sections.text:
In the design of NO2 degradation experiment, the light intensity inside the photocatalytic reaction chamber should be close to the UV intensity in the actual environment. Most of the UV radiation in the road environment is the long-wave UV radiation in the UVA band, so the UVA lamp tube with the lighting wavelength of 320–400 nm should be selected as the experiment light source.

Fig. 3. AC-13C dense-graded asph
In this experiment, the UV lamp was straight tube type with parameters of 30 W, 0.9 m long and 365 nm central wavelength. There were 5 lamps designed in the chamber as shown in Fig. 4.
Six rutting-plate specimens were placed directly below the lamp tube in the reaction room. The surface UV radiation intensity of the specimens below the X-axis is the same when the lamp tubes are symmetrical along the X-axis. Therefore, the measuring points were arranged at the symmetrical position of the rutting plate, as shown in Fig. 5(a). Photocatalytic degradation experiments were carried out when the tubes were opened at 1, 2, 4 and 5 because the UV radiation intensity at the central surface of the specimen is about 4.5 W/m2–5.5 W/m2, which is close to the environmental condition and between the Class-I and Class-II UV standards of China. The distribution of UV irradiation intensity on the surface of specimens was shown in Fig. 5(b).

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Gas concentration
sections.text:
In order to accurately simulate the actual road air environment, the concentration of NO2 in the air of typical road sections of Guangzhou (China) was investigated. Typical locations including toll stations, underpasses, tunnels and intersections. The data were collected at different time periods, traffic flow and different measuring points, and results were converted into 1 h average as shown in Fig. 6.
As shown in Fig. 6, the range of detected NO2 concentration is below 0.200 ppm in most cases. Also, considering China’s air quality standard (GB3095-2012), the average limit of NO2 for one hour is 250ug/m3 (about 0.125 ppm), so the optimum range of NO2 concentration in this test is selected as 0.125 ppm–0.200 ppm.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Test temperature
sections.text:
It is necessary to determine the appropriate test temperature before photocatalytic degradation of NO2 because there is a reversible reaction between NO2 and nitrogen oxide (N2O4), see Eq. (1). When the temperature is constant, the reversible reaction reaches equilibrium, and the ratio of NO2 to N2O4 is constant. The lower the temperature, the lower the concentration of NO2 detected. And it was found that the time needed to reach the fixed value of NO2 concentration in the reaction chamber was shorter when the control temperature was 27 C, and the detection of NO2 concentration
was appropriate. Therefore, the initial temperature is set at 27 C when the photocatalytic degradation of NO2 was carried out.
2NO2 ¢ Temp:Decrease
Temp:Increase N2O4 ð1Þ

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
3.1. High temperature properties of asphalt with nano-TiO2
sections.text:
In this experiment, the high temperature performance of asphalt with different nano-TiO2 content (S0, S1, S2, S5, S10) was tested, the relation between rutting factor G*/sind of asphalt with different nano-TiO2 content were shown in Fig. 7.
Also, as mentioned previously that the addition of cationic surfactants is beneficial to improve the dispersion properties of nanomaterials. Therefore, the impact of cationic surfactants on the high temperature performance of asphalt with 5% nano-TiO2 is compared and analyzed. The compare tests results of S5 and S5C were shown in Fig. 8. As shown in Figs. 7 and 8, it can be seen that:
1) The original SBS modified asphalt stopped DSR test at 82 C (G*/sind < 1), and the asphalt material with nano-TiO2 stopped DSR test at 88 C. The experimental data show that
ical data collection location.

64 70 76 82 88 94
G */
si nδ

)
Temperature(°C)
4# 6# S5 S5C
indicates that with the increase of temperature, the impact of nano-TiO2 content on the high temperature deformation resistance is reduced. 4) It can be seen from Fig. 8 that the DSR test of S5C sample stops at 94 C, which is higher than that of S5 sample at 88 C. At the same time, the rutting factor G*/sind of S5C asphalt is obviously higher than that of S5 asphalt, and the difference decreases gradually with the increase of temperature. It show that the high temperature deformation resistance of S5C asphalt is higher than that of S5 asphalt. The addition of cationic surfactants improves the rutting resistance and fatigue resistance of asphalt at high temperature.

sections.heading: 3.2. Low temperature properties of asphalt with nano-TiO2
3.2.1. BBR test results of S0–S10 asphalt
sections.text:
The low-temperature BBR tests of asphalt with different nanoTiO2 content (S0, S1, S2, S5, S10) were carried out. The test temperatures of BBR specimens were 6 C, 12 C, 18 C and the measuring time was 240 s. According to Superpave method, the creep stiffness S and creep rate m of asphalt beams at 60 s were used as the low temperature performance evaluation index of asphalt. The test stops when creep stiffness S 300 MPa or creep rate m 0.3. According to the results, the BBR test results of different nano-TiO2 content asphalt were shown in Fig. 9:
It can be seen from Fig. 9 that:
1) The BBR test results of all asphalt samples with different nano-TiO2 content at 6 C, 12 C, and 18 C meet the requirements of specifications: creep stiffness S 300 MPa or creep rate m 0.3; 2) The result show that the creep stiffness S and creep rate m of asphalt with different nano-TiO2 content are almost the same, which indicates that nano-TiO2 has little effect on the brittleness and low temperature crack resistance of asphalt, and it do not reduce the low temperature performance of asphalt.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. BBR test results of S5 and S5C asphalt
sections.text:
In order to study the impact of cationic surfactant on the low temperature performance of asphalt, the BBR test results of asphalt with 5% nano-TiO2 content and surfactant were compared and analyzed. The test result of creep stiffness S and creep rate m of both samples are shown in Fig. 10.
Compared with the creep stiffness of S5, the creep stiffness S of S5C gradually increases with the decrease of temperature, and the creep stiffness of S5C is obviously greater than the creep stiffness of S5 at 18 C. At this time, the brittleness of asphalt is significantly increased. Also, the creep rate m of S5C at different temper-
atures is lower than that of S5, indicating that the addition of surfactants reduced the low temperature cracking resistance.

sections.heading: 3.3. Aging properties of asphalt with different nano-TiO2 content
sections.text:
The aging performance of asphalt binder is generally evaluated by the changes of rheological indexes before and after asphalt aging. The commonly used method of simulating short-term aging of asphalt binder is RTFOT, and the long-term aging properties is normally evaluated with PAV tests.
The RTFOT and PAV samples were prepared following the Standard Test Methods of Bitumen and Bituminous Mixture for Highway Engineering (China) [31]. The result show that the weight loss rate after RTFOT of all samples are less than 1% which satisfy the specification requirement.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Effect of RTFOT aging on DSR test of asphalt
sections.text:
3.3.1.1. DSR test results of S0–S10 asphalt after RTFOT. The strain control mode of (10 ± 0.005)% was used in the DSR test, the test stops while G*/sind < 2.2 kPa. The test results of rutting factor G*/ sind were plotted in Fig. 11.
As it can see from the result:
1) After RTFOT aging, the DSR test of S0 asphalt was stopped at 76 C (G*/sind < 1). The tests of other asphalt with nano-TiO2 content were stopped at 88 C. The results showed that the complex shear modulus G* of asphalt increased after adding nano-TiO2 to asphalt after short-term aging, which means the rutting performance of at high temperature increases. 2) After RTFOT aging, when the content of nano-TiO2 in asphalt increases from 0% to 1%, the complex shear modulus G* and rutting factor G*/sind of asphalt increased significantly, which indicates that the addition of nano-TiO2 increases
the deformation resistance significantly. When the content of nano-TiO2 continues to increase from 1% to 10%, the G*, G*/sind of asphalt gradually increases, but the increase rate decreases with the increase of additive content. 3) The higher the temperature, the smaller the influence of nano-TiO2 content on the resistance of asphalt to high temperature deformation.
3.3.1.2. DSR test results of S5 and S5C asphalt after RTFOT. As can be seen from Fig. 12, after RTFOT, the G*/sind of S5 and S5C asphalt are almost the same which means the surfactant did not impact the fatigue resistance and rutting resistance of asphalt with 5% nanoTiO2. However, when compared the before and after aging of S5C sample, the stop temperature of DSR test of S5C asphalt drops to 88 C; it indicates that the surfactant decreases the high temperature deformation resistance of nano-TiO2 asphalt after RTFOT than before aging.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Effect of RTFOT aging on BBR test of asphalt
sections.text:
The creep stiffness S and creep rate m of modified asphalt with different aging degree (original, short-term aging and long-term aging) were tested by creep stiffness test of asphalt. According to these data, the effect of aging on low temperature performance of modified asphalt was analyzed.
3.3.2.1. BBR test results of S0–S10 asphalt after RTFOT. The BBR test steps are the same as the original asphalt, the test results are shown in Fig. 13. According to the test results, it can be seen that:
S0–S10 asphalt at 18 C does not meet the test requirements (creep stiffness S 300 MPa or creep rate m 0.3), while before aging, those five asphalt samples meet the requirements at 18 C, which indicating that the low temperature cracking resistance of asphalt after RTFOT decreases by one level;
As it can see from the values of creep stiffness S and creep rate m of S0–S10 asphalt at 6 C and 12 C, it can be seen that S and m are very similar to the asphalt without nano-TiO2 when the content of nano-TiO2 is between 0% and 10%, which indicating that the low temperature cracking resistance of asphalt with nano-TiO2 content is similar to that of SBS modified asphalt after shortterm aging.
3.3.2.2. BBR test results of S5 and S5C asphalt after RTFOT. The creep stiffness and creep rate of asphalt S5 and S5C are shown in Fig. 14. According to Fig. 14, when the temperature drops to 18 C, the creep stiffness S 300 MPa or m-value 0.3 which does not meet the specification requirements. Therefore, it only compared the S and m-value of S5 and S5C asphalt at 6 C and 12 C. The creep
stiffness S of S5 and S5C is similar at 6 C, but with the decrease of temperature, the creep stiffness of S5C increased obviously, the creep rate decreases, which indicating that the low temperature crack resistance of asphalt decreases.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Effect of PAV aging on BBR test of asphalt
sections.text:
3.3.3.1. BBR test results of S0–S10 asphalt after PAV. The BBR test procedure for asphalt after PAV is the same as that of the original asphalt. The test result of creep stiffness and creep rate are shown in Fig. 15.
As it can see from the results:
1) S0–S10 asphalt at 18 C does not meet the test requirements (creep stiffness S 300 MPa or creep rate m 0.3);
rate of asphalt after RTFOT.
p rate of asphalt after PAV.
2) It can be seen from the results at 6 C and 12 C that when the content of nano-TiO2 is less than 5%, the effect of nano-TiO2 on the low temperature crack resistance of asphalt is small.
3.3.3.2. BBR test results of S5 and S5C asphalt after PAV. According to Fig. 16, when the temperature drops to 18 C, the S 300 MPa or m 0.3 of RTFOT aged asphalt which does not meet the requirements. Therefore, it only compared the S and m of S5 and S5C asphalt at 6 C and 12 C. The creep stiffness S of S5 and S5C is similar at 6 C, but with the decrease of temperature, the creep stiffness of S5C increased obviously, the creep rate decreases, which indicating that the addition of surfactant reduces the low temperature cracking resistance of asphalt with 5% nano-TiO2 content after long-term aging.

sections.heading: 3.4. NO2 degradation test result of asphalt mixture
sections.text:
The NO2 degradation tests were conducted on S5 rutting plate specimens. The NO2 analyzer was turned on when the temperature of the reaction room was constant at 27 C. After about 1.5 h, the measured concentration was stable at about 0.157 ppm. The temperature and relative humidity at this time were recorded, and the UV lamp tube was turned on. After turning on the lamp, the temperature of the reaction room rose to 30 31 C. The NO2 concentration was recorded continuously until the temperature is stable again, the UV lamp is turned off and the experiment is finished. Two parallel tests were carried out, and the NO2 concentration of both tests was shown in Fig. 17(a) and (b) respectively.
According to the NO2 concentration with time relation, it can see that:
rate vs. time relation.
p rate of asphalt after PAV.
1) In Period-1, the temperature and humidity in the light reaction chamber were constant before the UV lamp tube turned on, the concentration of NO2 detected by the analyzer increased and gradually stabilized at (0.155 ± 0.005) ppm. 2) After the UV lamp is turned on, the concentration of NO2 in the reaction chamber in the Period-2 increases gradually and reaches the peak at about 03:20:00; in Period-3, the detected concentration of NO2 decreases gradually from the peak value, and its decreasing rate decreases gradually with the increase of time; the temperature in the photoreaction chamber was gradually stable again in Period-4, and NO2 concentration in the reaction chamber was gradually constant as well.
There are two reasons for NO2 concentration to increase first and then decrease after the UV lamp is turned on:
1) At the initial stage after the UV lamps turned on, the heat generated by the lamps caused the temperature in the photoreaction chamber to rise, so the balance between NO2 and N2O4 in the reaction chamber is broken, and produced more NO2 (see Equation (1)) which resulting in the increase of NO2 concentration in the reaction chamber. The total NO2 increase indicating that NO2 produced by reversible reaction is larger than the consumption of NO2 in degradation reaction. 2) Later in the Period-3 and Period-4 after UV lamps turned on, temperature becomes stable and the concentration of NO2 decreases, which indicates that the consumption of NO2 in degradation reaction exceeds that of NO2 produced by reversible reaction, the concentration of NO2 in photoreaction chamber begins to decrease. See Equation (2) for the photocatalytic degradation of NO2 by nano-TiO2.
2H2Oþ 4NO2 þ O2 !TiO2 UV 4HNO3 ð2Þ

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this research, the rheological properties at high temperature, low temperature crack resistance and aging properties of SBS modified asphalt blended with nano-TiO2 were evaluated. Also the degradation of NO2 in asphalt mixture with nano-TiO2 was analyzed. According to the test result, the following conclusions can be drawn:
1) After adding nano-TiO2 into SBS modified asphalt, the high temperature grade of the original asphalt increased from 76 C to 82 C and the low temperature grade was 18 C. Then after RTFOT aging, the high temperature grade of asphalt increased from 70 C to 82 C and the low temperature grade increased to 12 C, and the low temperature grade after PAV aging was 12 C as well. The results show that the addition of nano-TiO2 can improve the fatigue and rutting resistance of SBS modified asphalt, and the hightemperature and low-temperature performance of asphalt decreases after aging. 2) The G*/sind increased about 1.5 times when the content of nano-TiO2 varies from 0% to 1%, the impact of nano-TiO2 on the G*/sind becomes less when the content of nanoTiO2 increases from 1% to 10%. 3) When the content of nano-TiO2 is in the range of 0% 5%, the creep stiffness S of non-aging, RTFO aging and PAV aging asphalt gradually decreases, the brittleness of asphalt performance decreases, and the low-temperature crack
resistance of asphalt is slightly improved; when the content of nano-TiO2 increases from 5% to 10%, the impact of nanoTiO2 content on the low-temperature crack resistance of asphalt is small. 4) After adding cationic surfactant, the rutting resistance of asphalt with 5% nano-TiO2 content at high temperature is increased, but the cracking resistance at low temperature decreases. And the lower the temperature it is, the more impact of surfactant on the low temperature cracking resistance. 5) The addition of nano-TiO2 improves the high temperature performance of SBS modified asphalt. With the increase of nano-TiO2 content, the rutting factor G*/sind increases, but the impact of nano-TiO2 decrease with the increase of additive amount. 6) The asphalt mixture with 5% nano-TiO2 exhibits good photocatalytic degradation of NO2 under the test conditions.
Declaration of Competing Interest
None.

referenceMentions.context: conducted extensive investigations to explore materials which are able to degrade NO2, and it was found that, as photocatalytic material, certain nano-particles can undergo redox reaction under UV irradiation to achieve the degradation of harmful substances [1].
In 1972, Fujishima and Hond [2] found that TiO2 has catalytic redox properties under light irradiation.
Brown (1984) [3], Cui et al (1995) [4], Voront et al.
Brown (1984) [3], Cui et al (1995) [4], Voront et al.
(2003) [5] analyzed that TiO2 can applied as photocatalyst to oxidize and degrade harmful gases such as NO2 and CO; Muggli et al (2000) [6], Lee et al.
(2003) [5] analyzed that TiO2 can applied as photocatalyst to oxidize and degrade harmful gases such as NO2 and CO; Muggli et al (2000) [6], Lee et al.
(2004) [7] pointed out that TiO2 can degrade NO2, atmospheric sulfides and organic waste gas, and can be used for indoor air quality treatment.
For example, Chiba, Japan built a highway that uses the pore structure on the road surface to load TiO2 powder to achieve the effect of photocatalytic degradation of automobile exhaust gas [8].
In 2002, researchers in Milan, Italy evaluated the photocatalytic degradation effect of nano-TiO2 and laid a test section of 7000 m(2) in the form of coating [9].
The Antwerp City Park in Belgium constructed a sidewalk of about 10,000 m(2) with cement concrete bricks containing nano-TiO2 [10].
In Guerville, France, nano-TiO2 was sprayed on the walls of three buildings to study its degradation of NO2 in the atmosphere [11].
Chen et al (2006, 2007) found that the cured cement specimens exhibited good degradation performance of NO2 in the atmosphere under UV irradiation [12].

Zouzelka et al, investigated the photocatalytic activity of nano-TiO2 with regard to NO and NO2 abatement and have applied to the surface of concrete walls in field, and the photocatalytic coating maintained high effectivity after two years of service [13].
João Victor Staub de Melo et al produced blocks with a photocatalytic surface through the incorporation of TiO2 [14].
) had significant effect on NO2 degradation [15].
PérezNicolás evaluated the Portland cements with two doped TiO2 (FeTiO2 and V-TiO2) photocatalysts and found those enhanced NO removal under visible light [16].
(2011) analyzed the degradation performance of NOx by adding TiO2 into asphalt specimens, and found that the physical properties of asphalt were not adversely affected after adding nano-TiO2 [17].
analyzed the influence of TiO2 on penetration, ductility and softening point of asphalt, and provided reference for determining the amount of TiO2 additive in engineering practice [18].
Zhang et al found that nano-TiO2 modified asphalt had the ability to resist UV aging [19].

found that nano-TiO2 powder can improve the pavement performance of asphalt mixture comprehensively by high temperature rutting test, low temperature bending beam rheology test and residual stability test [20].
found that the content of nano-TiO2 needed by the incorporation method was much larger than that of the coating method when the same degradation effect was achieved [21].
The NOx catalytic degradation performance of the specimen before and after wearing was studied and the permeation effect of the prepared permeate was analyzed [22].

Sun et al [23] have studied the decomposition effect of nano-TiO2 on NOx under different mixing order and gradation of asphalt mixture and have concluded that the direct mixing method is suitable for large-scale road construction.

And after one year of field use, the sampling test results show that it still has good catalytic degradation efficiency, indicating that the asphalt pavement structure has good fixation effect on nano-TiO2 [24].
Wang, et al [25,26] developed a newmethod to coat TiO2 onto asphalt pavements with the aim to enhance the NOx decomposition efficiency and durability of the coating material for asphalt pavements.
Wang, et al [25,26] developed a newmethod to coat TiO2 onto asphalt pavements with the aim to enhance the NOx decomposition efficiency and durability of the coating material for asphalt pavements.
Fan et al [27] conducted chamber tests of NOx removal under simulated condition and show that NOx removal by C-TiO2 photocatalytic asphalt is viable and is better than conventional used P25.
[29] also conducted experimental investigation of effect of nanoTiO2 modified bitumen on the performance of asphalt mixtures.

TiO2 has advantages of abundant sources and relatively lower cost, which occurs in nature as well-knownminerals rutile, anatase and brookite, the main resource to produce is TiO2 from ilmenite ore [30].
